solution.introduction: Think about the "task" that machine translation programs expected to carry out? How can we capture "experience" that might be relevant to the task of translation? What "performance" measures are applied to machine translation engines?
solution.sample:
We can understand translation data, captured, for example, in translation memories or parallel corpora, as "experience". The "performance" of a machine learning algortihm that learns to translate from such translation data can be measured using a variety of automatic metrics (covered in chapter 3 of the MultitraiNMT book). One such metric is called "bleu", but there are lots of other metrics (WER, chrF3, and so on) than can be used to show that a machine translation engine is improving. The "task" in the case of machine translation is to translate sentences or, preferably, full texts that the engine hasn't already encountered in its experience so far (that is, in training).
 
So, a machine translation program that gets better and better (as measured by a performance metric like bleu or WER) at translating new texts (the task), the more it is exposed to training data (experience), is a great example of machine learning in action.

taskDescription:
Tom Mitchell (1997, cited in Goodfellow et al. 2016: 97) provides the following succinct deﬁnition of machine learning:

 

“A computer program is said to learn from experience E with respect to some class of tasks T and performance measure P, if its performance at tasks in T, as measured by P, improves with experience E.”

 

Can you exaplain how this general machine learning framework, comprising (1) experience, (2) task and (3) performance, can be applied to machine translation? Use the Help text below to guide you. A sample solution is also provided below.
